question: 1 (l)
sols_html:
We proceed in the hint and try to solve for k where

\(\displaystyle 1 = \int_{-\infty}^{1}ke^{-x}e^{(-e^{-x})}\)

First, we change the improper integral to

\(\displaystyle 1 = \lim_{b \to -\infty} \int_{b}^{1}ke^{-x}e^{(-e^{-x})}\)

Let \(\displaystyle u = -e^{-x}\) so that \(\displaystyle du = e^{-x}dx\) and the endpoints change to

\(\displaystyle u(1) = -e^{-1} \qquad u(b) = -e^{-b}\)

This gives

\[\begin{aligned} 1 &= \lim_{b \to -\infty} \int_{b}^{1}ke^{-x}e^{(-e^{-x})}\\ &= \lim_{b \to -\infty} \int_{ -e^{-b}}^{ -e^{-1}}ke^{u}\,du\\ &= \lim_{b \to -\infty} ke^{u}\Bigr|_{ -e^{-b}}^{ -e^{-1}}\\ &= \lim_{b \to -\infty} k(e^{ -e^{-1}} - e^{ -e^{-b}})\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\lim_{b \to -\infty} -b = +\infty\) we have that \(\lim_{b \to -\infty} e^{-b} = +\infty\). Using this yields that \(\lim_{b \to -\infty} -e^{-b} = -\infty\) and hence \(\lim_{b \to -\infty} e^{-e^{-b}} = 0\). Thus the second term in the long equation above vanishes and we finally conclude that

\(\displaystyle 1 = ke^{ -e^{-1}}\)

Solving gives \(\displaystyle e^{ e^{-1}} = k\)

statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Let \(k\) be a constant. Find the value of \(k\) such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = ke^{-x}e^{(-e^{-x})}\end{aligned}\]

is a probability density function on \((-\infty,1]\).
